Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: A Principled Approach to Enabling Policy Transparency for Mobile Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rise in popularity of bandwidth-hungry applications such as video streaming, and the popularity of resource-constrained mobile networks has reignited discussions about how network traffic associated with different applications is treated by Internet Service Providers (ISPs). To manage scarce network resources, ISPs use middleboxes to selectively enforce network policies (e.g., limit transfer rates for video streaming). This study will explore the impact of middleboxes on network traffic, and lead network users, policymakers, and regulators to a deeper understanding of policies deployed in operational networks.

This project addresses three key challenges that limit researchers' understanding of network policies imposed by middleboxes. First, researchers struggle to characterize policies because they have limited or no access to middleboxes for experimentation. Second, researchers lack models of how middleboxes classify and interact with network traffic, making it difficult to reason about them. Finally, identifying and understanding middlebox behavior often requires measurements from vantage points inside the network. This investigation entails black-box and grey-box experiments on commercial middleboxes to build accurate models of how they operate, and using these observations to build a scalable, flexible and realistic testbed for evaluating methods to detect and isolate network policies. This project will incorporate trace-based analysis to design efficient, resilient algorithms to detect these properties from end systems, and optimizations to make this detection system scale. To generalize our results, the PIs will develop a theory of how middleboxes can impact traffic, how to detect these middleboxes from endpoints, potentially with limited visibility into the network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internet service provider (ISP) policies that impact network traffic can have significant implications for performance, quality of experience, and innovation. For example, most cellular providers in the US slow down streaming video so that it cannot achieve high resolution, and they do so in uneven ways (i.e., some video providers are affected while others are not). Without regulation or accountability, such network management practices could be misused to raise the barrier to entry for new technologies, or block them entirely. Further, these practices that violate net neutrality can worsen the user experience, and have disparate impacts on different populations (e.g., by slowing down educational videos for those who have no choice but to use a cellular plan to access the Internet). 

One of the biggest challenges when addressing accountability is that ISPs do not disclose exactly how they implement such practices, nor were there existing tools that allow us to confidently conclude that ISPs are engaging in differential treatment of applications (e.g., slowing down some applications but not others). This project addressed these challenges by developing new algorithms and software implementations to reveal how ISPs implement practices that discriminate against certain types of applications, to identify how these implementations are flawed and can harm non-targeted applications while allowing other applications to evade detection, and to use data gathered from more than 1 million tests run by users of our software to reliably identify differentiation practices at a global scale.

In addition to dissemination in research publication venues, this project led to the development of Wehe, a free iOS and Android app that implements the above research for identifying traffic differentiation practices. It has been available for more than three years, attracting more than 130,000 users globally who use the app to detect net neutrality violations, cumulatively running more than 1.7 million tests. The project also resulted in a public website (https://wehe.meddle.mobi) with regularly updated findings regarding which ISPs are throttling network traffic corresponding to popular content providers (e.g., YouTube, Netflix, etc). These public findings have received significant attention in the popular press and driven policy discussions in the U.S. and abroad. Arcep, the French national telecom regulator, is using the Wehe system as the official way to detect net neutrality violations in France (where such violations are illegal). 

This project analyzed Wehe data to determine which carriers are giving different performance to certain apps, and to determine details about how such apps are being differentiated---typically fixed-rate throttling (i.e., limiting bandwidth available to a fixed, lower amount than offered to other apps). It also investigated how these policies change over time, particularly in light of regulatory changes. Combined with our findings about limitations of throttling implementations (their susceptibility to creating unlevel playing fields, worsening user experience, and causing network inefficiencies), we argue that such policies are difficult to get right, may cause more harm than good, and in many cases should be disallowed so that users and content providers are offered a more open and transparent Internet where new and existing applications can thrive.
